The QRS complexes will be wide and bizarre. It stops spontaneously within 30 seconds. Check all leads for a comprehensive view.
non-specific inferior/lateral ST changes: Focus on leads II, III, aVF (inferior) and I, aVL, V5-V6 (lateral). Look for ST-segment elevation or depression, T-wave inversion, or abnormal Q-waves. These changes may indicate myocardial ischemia or injury. Always correlate with clinical symptoms and patient history.
low voltage in the precordial leads: Low voltage in precordial leads is diagnosed when the R wave in leads V4-V6 or the S wave in V1-V3 is less than 5mm. Focus on these leads and measure the amplitude of these waves.
non-specific anteroseptal ST-T changes: Look for changes in leads V1-V4, which represent the anteroseptal area. Non-specific ST-T changes can include ST segment depression or elevation, T wave inversion, or abnormal Q waves. These changes may indicate ischemia, injury, or infarction. Always correlate with clinical symptoms.
QRS changes: Focus on leads II, III, and aVF for inferior changes; V1-V4 for anterior changes; I, aVL, V5, V6 for lateral changes. Look for QRS duration, axis deviation, abnormal Q waves, R wave progression, and bundle branch blocks.
incomplete left bundle branch block: Look for slightly prolonged QRS duration (90-120 ms) in lead V6. There should be a small R wave followed by a larger S wave in V1, and a broad monophasic R wave in V6. These are key signs of incomplete left bundle branch block.
low R waves in anteroseptal leads: Focus on leads V1-V4 for anteroseptal R waves. Low R waves may indicate myocardial infarction. Look for small or absent R waves, ST segment depression, and T wave inversion. Always compare with previous ECGs if available.
aberrant ventricular conduction: Look for wide QRS complexes (>120 ms) in the ECG. In leads V1-V3, if the QRS complex is predominantly negative, it suggests left bundle branch block. If it's predominantly positive, it suggests right bundle branch block.
biatrial enlargement: Biatrial enlargement is diagnosed on a 12-lead ECG by looking for P wave changes. In lead II, a bifid P wave with >40ms between peaks suggests left atrial enlargement. In V1, a biphasic P wave with a terminal negative component >40ms indicates right atrial enlargement.
atrioventricular junctional rhythm: Look for a regular rhythm with a rate of 40-60 bpm, absent P waves or P waves after the QRS complex, and a narrow QRS complex in the 12-lead ECG. This indicates an atrioventricular junctional rhythm.
accelerated idioventricular rhythm: Look for a regular rhythm with a rate of 40-120 bpm, wide QRS complexes (>120 ms), and absence of P waves before each QRS complex. The rhythm originates from the ventricles, hence the term idioventricular. It's faster than normal idioventricular rhythm, hence accelerated.
non-specific septal T wave changes: Look for T wave inversion or flattening in septal leads (V1-V2). However, non-specific septal T wave changes can be normal variants. Always correlate with clinical history, other ECG findings, and consider further testing if needed.
anterolateral myocardial ischemic: Look for ST-segment depression or T-wave inversion in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6. These changes suggest anterolateral myocardial ischemia. Also, consider patient symptoms and risk factors for a comprehensive diagnosis.
junctional tachycardia: Look for a heart rate over 100 bpm, narrow QRS complexes, and absent or inverted P waves before the QRS complex in leads II, III, and aVF. This indicates junctional tachycardia.
inferior and septal ST segment elevation: Inferior ST elevation is seen in leads II, III, and aVF. Septal ST elevation appears in V1 and V2. Look for upward deflection from baseline after QRS complex. This indicates myocardial ischemia or injury.
myocardial ischemia: Look for ST-segment depression or T-wave inversion in leads V1-V6, I, aVL (lateral ischemia) or II, III, aVF (inferior). ST-elevation may indicate acute myocardial infarction. Also, check for Q waves, which suggest past infarction.
ST segment elevation: Look for a J-point elevation of >1mm in two contiguous leads in 12-lead ECG. The ST segment should be concave or horizontal. Check leads V1-V6, II, III, aVF for anterior and inferior wall elevation. Leads I, aVL, V5, V6 indicate lateral wall elevation.
anterior ST segment elevation: Look for ST segment elevation in the precordial leads V1-V4. This indicates an anterior myocardial infarction. The ST segment should be elevated >1mm above the isoelectric line, 80ms after the J point. Also, reciprocal changes may be seen in inferior leads (II, III, aVF).
anterior myocardial infarction: Look for ST-segment elevation in the anterior precordial leads (V1-V4) on a 12-lead ECG. This elevation, along with reciprocal changes in other leads, indicates an anterior myocardial infarction.
left axis deviation: Check leads I and aVF on the ECG. If the QRS complex is negative in lead aVF and positive in lead I, it indicates left axis deviation. This is due to the heart's electrical axis shifting more to the left than normal.
uncontrolled ventricular response: Look for irregular rhythm, absence of P waves, and rapid ventricular rate (100-180 bpm) in all leads. Specifically, in leads V1-V2, you may see a 'sawtooth' pattern. This suggests uncontrolled ventricular response in conditions like atrial fibrillation.
borderline septal T wave changes: Look for T wave inversion in leads V1-V3. If inversion is less than 1mm, it's borderline. Also, consider patient's age, sex, and race. Rule out right bundle branch block, right ventricular hypertrophy, or pulmonary disease. Always correlate with clinical history.
anterolateral myocardial infarction: Look for ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6. Reciprocal changes may appear in inferior leads. Q waves may develop. These indicate an anterolateral myocardial infarction.
acute inferior myocardial infarction: Look for ST-segment elevation in inferior leads (II, III, aVF). Reciprocal changes (ST depression) may appear in aVL or I. Presence of Q waves in these leads may indicate older infarction. Confirm with clinical symptoms and biomarkers.
extensive ST elevation: Look for ST segment elevation in two contiguous leads. Extensive ST elevation often indicates a major heart attack. It's typically seen in leads V1-V6, I, aVL (anterior or lateral wall) or II, III, aVF (inferior wall). The elevation should be >1mm in limb leads and >2mm in precordial leads.
sinus/ectopic atrial rhythm: Look for regular rhythm and rate (60-100 bpm) for sinus rhythm. P waves should be upright in leads I, II, aVF and V2-V6. For ectopic atrial rhythm, rate is usually 60-100 bpm, but P waves may have abnormal morphology or direction.
marked ST segment depression in V1,V2,V3: Look for a downward sloping or horizontal ST segment that's below the baseline in leads V1-V6. This is ST segment depression. It's marked if it's ≥0.5mm. It may indicate myocardial ischemia or other cardiac conditions. Always correlate with clinical symptoms.
non-specific inferior ST segment changes: Focus on leads II, III, and aVF for inferior changes. Look for ST segment depression or elevation, T wave inversion, or abnormal Q waves. These changes may indicate ischemia, injury, or infarction. Always correlate with clinical symptoms and patient history.
lateral myocardial injury: Lateral myocardial injury is typically indicated on a 12-lead ECG by ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6. Look for Q waves and T wave inversion as well.
Q waves in anteroseptal leads: Focus on leads V1-V4 for anteroseptal Q waves. Look for a Q wave duration >0.04 seconds or a Q wave depth >25% of the following R wave. These may indicate myocardial infarction.
QRS axis leftward: Look at leads I and aVF. If QRS complex is positive in lead I and negative in aVF, the QRS axis is leftward. This indicates Left Axis Deviation, often due to left ventricular hypertrophy or left anterior fascicular block.
dextrocardia: In dextrocardia, ECG shows right axis deviation, positive QRS complex in aVR, and negative in lead I. P, QRS, and T waves are inverted in leads I, aVL, and often V4-V6. These are key features to focus on.
ventricular pre-excitation: Look for a short PR interval (<120 ms) and a delta wave (slurred upstroke at the start of the QRS complex) in the 12-lead ECG. These are hallmark signs of ventricular pre-excitation.
non-specific anterolateral ST segment ch: Look for ST segment changes in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6. These represent the anterolateral wall. Non-specific changes can include ST elevation, depression, or T-wave inversion. However, these changes should be interpreted in clinical context as they can also occur in normal variants.
sinus/ectopic atrial bradycardia: Look for a heart rate below 60 bpm on the ECG. Sinus bradycardia will have a regular P wave before each QRS complex. Ectopic atrial bradycardia will have irregular P waves or P waves that differ in shape. Check all 12 leads for consistency.
paired ventricular premature complexes: Look for two premature ventricular complexes (PVCs) in a row on the ECG. They appear as wide, bizarre QRS complexes without a preceding P wave, often followed by a compensatory pause. They can be seen in any lead but are most noticeable in the chest leads (V1-V6).
marked precordial ST segment depression: Look for ST segment depression in precordial leads (V1-V6). Marked depression is typically >2mm below baseline. It may indicate myocardial ischemia, ventricular hypertrophy, or digitalis effect. Always correlate with patient symptoms and history.
anterior Q waves: Anterior Q waves are diagnosed on 12-lead ECG by observing leads V1-V4. Look for a small negative deflection (Q wave) before the R wave. Pathological Q waves are typically >40ms wide and >2mm deep, indicating possible anterior myocardial infarction.
old anteroseptal myocardial infarction: Look for pathological Q waves in leads V1-V3, indicative of old anteroseptal myocardial infarction. These are Q waves >0.04 seconds or a QS complex in these leads. Also, check for ST-T wave changes, but they may normalize over time.
non-specific anterior ST segment changes: Focus on leads V1-V4 for anterior changes. Look for ST segment elevation or depression, T wave inversion, or abnormal Q waves. These changes may indicate myocardial ischemia, injury, or infarction. Always correlate with clinical symptoms and patient history.
abnormal ventricular conduction pathways: Look for wide QRS complexes (>120ms) in the ECG. Leads V1-V3 can show bundle branch blocks. Right bundle branch block (RBBB) shows 'M' shape in V1 and 'W' in V6. Left bundle branch block (LBBB) shows 'W' in V1 and 'M' in V6.
inferior and lateral ST-T changes: Inferior ST-T changes are seen in leads II, III, and aVF. Lateral ST-T changes appear in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6. Look for ST-segment elevation or depression, T-wave inversion, or abnormal Q-waves in these leads.
atrial flutter: Look for regular atrial activity at around 300 bpm in leads II, III, and aVF. The classic "sawtooth" pattern, especially in inferior leads, is indicative of atrial flutter. Also, check for variable ventricular response.
Q waves in inferior and anterior/septal: Look for Q waves in inferior leads (II, III, aVF) and anterior/septal leads (V1-V4). Q waves are normal if <0.04s wide and <25% of the following R wave. Pathological Q waves suggest myocardial infarction.
abnormal R wave progression: Look at precordial leads V1-V6. Normal R wave progression: R wave gets larger and S wave gets smaller from V1 to V6. Abnormal progression: R wave stays small or S wave stays large in V4-V6, or sudden change in R/S ratio.
old anterolateral myocardial infarction: Look for pathological Q waves in the anterolateral leads (I, aVL, V4-V6). These indicate old myocardial infarction. Also, check for ST segment and T wave changes. Reduced R wave progression can also be a sign.
